to cover today is the storage classes for amazon's simple storage service commonly referred to as s3 there are six
storage classes that differ in pricing and behavior so it is important to choose the right one for your data based
on use case and performance requirements starting with s3 standard although this
class costs the most per gigabyte it is the most effective cost-effective storage class for frequently accessed
data because it does not charge a data retrieval fee compare that to s3 standard infrequent
access or standard ia this class is almost half the price of standard in terms of per gigabyte storage but it
does have data retrieval fees it also has a minimum storage duration of 30 days meaning if an object is
transitioned to a different storage class before 30 days pass you will still be charged the full 30 days that said
standard ia is ideal for data that is not accessed frequently but requires rapid access when needed
the next class s31 zone ia is similar to standard ia except data is stored in a
single availability zone and is not resilient in the event that a z were to
be destroyed because of the reduced resiliency one zone ia is 20 cheaper than standard ia
s3 glacier is a storage class that is 83 percent cheaper than standard but also
has a standard latency of several hours when retrieving data although this can be expedited by paying a premium
because it also has a minimum storage duration of 90 days s3 glacier is suitable for data archiving and backups
that likely won't be accessed and even colder storage is s3 glacier
deep archive which offers the lowest cost per gigabyte storage on aws at 96 percent
the cost of standard however it does have the highest latency with a data retrieval time of up to 12 hours that
cannot be expedited it is designed for the long-term retention of data that will be retained
for 7 to 10 years the last storage class is s3 intelligent tiering which is designed to optimize
costs and reduce operational overhead by automatically transitioning objects between storage classes based on when
they were last accessed as an example when an object is first created with intelligent tiering it
starts as standard but if the object hasn't been accessed in 30 days intelligent tiering will automatically
move the object to standard ia then if the object is accessed intelligent turn will move the object
back to standard and the transition timer will reset something important to highlight is that intelligent tiering has no retrieval
fees minimum storage durations or minimum buildable object sizes and aws
recently announced the removal of the monitoring fee for objects smaller than 128 kilobytes
additionally you can opt into s3 glacier and s3 glacier deep archive classes as well
for these reasons intelligent tiering is ideal for objects with unknown changing or unpredictable access patterns
regardless of size or lifespan now i want to provide a similar overview
for ebs volume types which are the black storage attached to ec2 compute

now with our provision iops ssds io1 and io2 these volume types provide the
highest performance but in return cost 25 more than gp2 io2 volumes also support black express

first is a transition rule which will automatically transition objects to a lower storage class after a set number

okay so a couple of cost optimization principles in accordance with the aws
well architected framework are modernization right sizing and elasticity as a best practice customers
should develop an internal strategy to monitor for these for these
principles to accelerate the value realization of the cloud modernization is the process of
upgrading to current generation technology as it is not only faster but also cheaper
right sizing is the process of matching infrastructure with the performance and capacity requirements of its underlying
workloads and elasticity is the ability to acquire and release resources based on need
as cloud technology continues to evolve at a rapid rate optimization is a continuous process that should be
revisited on a regular basis if you have any questions on these topics as we go through them make sure
to ask them in the chat and we'll be sure to address them so starting with modernization there are
many modernization paths available but we're just going to focus on two today the first is the aws graviton 2
processor which for amazon ec2 instances these arm based processors deliver seven times the
performance at twenty percent the cost graviton two processors are also
available for amazon rds amazon elastic cash amazon open search service and aws
lambda functions as well the other modernization as we touched on previously was modernizing your ebs
volumes from gp2 to gp3 and io1 to io2 gp3 volumes have 20 percent cheaper
black storage and as clint mentioned you can also scale iops and throughput independent of your storage capacity
unlike gp2 and with io2 volumes they offer 10 times more apps per gigabyte than i one and
offer economies of scale for provision iops coin how have customers that you support
successfully migrated workloads from traditional intel based processors to graviton processors
thanks tom so what we're seeing customers that aren't leveraging third-party off-the-shelf application

ec2 auto scaling groups are a way to account for workloads with large demand spikes a scaling plan can be configured

with scheduling use aws instant scheduler a cloud formation solution for

pricing models and it's important to understand when to use each one in order to optimize costs
so to start on-demand instances allow you to pay as you go so this pricing model is the most
flexible and capacities billed by the hour or second depending on resources running in the account
on-demand instances are often used when workloads are first provisioned on aws as they provide the ability to start and
stop billing of those resources as necessary moving on to savings plans so savings
plans provide discounts on top of resources that are running steadily and in order to receive the savings plan
discount rates you will commit to a specific dollar per hour value for a one
or three year time frame savings plans are a flexible pricing model that is best used for steady state
compute workloads um reserve instances also provide
discounts on top of resources running steadily however they're not as flexible as savings plans so with the reserved
instance you're committing to a specific resource with specific characteristics for a one
or three year time frame spot instances finally are
spot instances allow you to use unused ec2 capacity at a discounted rate of up
to 90 off uh compared to on-demand pricing uh so spot instances are best for
workloads that can stand to be interrupted when aws needs to reclaim the capacity of the underlying ec2
instance back now that we've gone through an overview of the different pricing models let's
take a closer look starting with savings plans
so savings plans as i mentioned are a discounted rate on top of resources that are running steadily and with the
savings plan you're committing to a specific dollar per hour value for one or three years
this commitment has three different payment options all up front partial up front or no up
front and there are two different types of savings plans for compute workloads uh so the first is ec2 instance savings
plans which are going to offer you the greatest percent of discount with savings up to 72 percent compared to
on-demand ec2 instant savings plans are flexible across instant size
operating system and tenancy this means that if any of those variables were to change for example if
you were running an m5 extra large and you moved to an m54 extra large
since that's a change in instant size the savings plan discount rate will still be applied
and the compute savings plan on the other hand will not offer as high of a percentage of discount however it does
will provide the highest the greatest amount of flexibility so compute savings plan discounts are
flexible across instance family aws region operating system tenancy and along with
